scenes.text: You land in a new country with nothing but a suitcase and a low-battery phone. You can't read the signs.

choices.text: Try to ask someone for directions using broken language.
Use your phone to find a map.
Wait around, hoping someone approaches you.

scenes.text: You get vague directions and take the wrong train. A kind older man notices your struggle.

choices.text: Ask for help again.
Pretend you know what you're doing.

scenes.text: You find a café with Wi-Fi, but they ask you to buy something first.

choices.text: Buy a coffee and use the Wi-Fi.
Ask to use Wi-Fi without buying anything.

scenes.text: The man helps you find your way and gives you tips for surviving the city.

choices.text: Thank him and continue on your own.
Ask if he knows someone renting a cheap place.

scenes.text: You walk through a neighborhood that reminds you of home. A local cultural center invites you in.

choices.text: Join a traditional music class.
Ignore it. Focus on finding a job.

scenes.text: You get a small room. The landlord is shady and asks for extra under the table.

choices.text: Pay it to avoid trouble.
Refuse. Report it.

scenes.text: You apply for cleaning and delivery jobs. Interviews go badly due to language barriers.

choices.text: Keep trying and use Grandma’s phrasebook.
Fake your experience and lie.

scenes.text: You learn new things about your own roots and meet others from your homeland.

choices.text: Form a WhatsApp group to help newcomers.
Keep to yourself and just attend events.

scenes.text: Your effort pays off. You now understand basic conversations and feel more confident.

choices.text: Apply to a community college for night classes.
Look for better jobs with new skills.

scenes.text: Months have passed. You reflect on where you are now. Your stats determine your ending.

choices.text: End Game

scenes.text: You report the shady landlord, but things escalate quickly. The authorities get involved, and your immigration status becomes a bigger issue. After a few days, you are detained and told to leave the country.

choices.text: Fight it out in court.
Give up and accept deportation.

scenes.text: You lie about your previous work experience and land a job as a cleaner in a hotel. The pay is miserable, and the work conditions are harsh. After a month of being overworked and underpaid, you’re let go.

choices.text: Try to find another job immediately.
Give up and return to your home country.

scenes.text: You start a small support group for newcomers and people struggling with the same challenges. Slowly, you build a network of people who help each other with housing, jobs, and emotional support.

choices.text: Use the group’s resources to help you find better work.
Focus more on building your own life and attend group meetings less.

scenes.text: You’ve been keeping to yourself, just attending cultural events occasionally but not getting too involved. You have a steady routine, but the isolation is starting to take a toll on your mental health.

choices.text: Push yourself to engage more with people.
Stick with your routine and avoid any more disruptions.

scenes.text: You sit there, frozen by fear and self-doubt. By the time you gather your thoughts, the chance to get help has passed. You feel alone and isolated.

choices.text: Try to find another opportunity later.
Give up on your new life here.

scenes.text: You’ve become a bridge for others. Fluent, connected, and proud of your roots.
You've made it. Good job, good money — but sometimes you wonder what you left behind.
You’ve built a life and brought your people with you. The old and new now live inside you.
You pushed hard, but never paused. Somewhere along the way, you lost yourself.
It became too much. You didn’t have the support or the system. You're going home — for now.
